title: In the absence of any generally accepted decipherment of Harappan script, evidence on the Indus Valley civilization is limited to archaeological data and what can be deduced, with varying degrees of credibility, from supposed survivals in later Indian culture, and the available books reflect this situation. Deserving mention is Sir Mortimer Wheeler, The Indus Civilization
The Harappan Civilisation (Aris and Phillips, 1982) is more useful to the professional archaeologist than to the general reader

container-title: Anthes on 'Mythology in Ancient Egypt'. H. Franfort et al., Before Philosophy (Penguin, 1949), deals in an interesting way with the basic religious concepts of both ancient Egypt and ancient Mesopotamia; its approach is indicated by its sub-titles 'The Intellectual Adventure of Ancient Man; an Essay on Speculative Thought in the Ancient Near East'
title: Mythologies of the Ancient World (Anchor Books, 1961) contains some important material on the relationship of mythology to ancient religion, particularly an essay by R
